skill.name: reducing-entropy
skill.description: Manual-only skill for minimizing total codebase size. Only activate when explicitly requested by user. Measures success by final code amount, not effort. Bias toward deletion.
skill.summary: Manual skill that guides AI to minimize codebase size by evaluating every change against total code reduction metrics
skill.author: softaworks

security_audit.summary: This is a manual-only documentation skill with no scripts, no executable code, and no network capabilities. All static scanner findings are false positives triggered by markdown documentation patterns (code spans, external reference links, YAML frontmatter). The skill only contains philosophical guidance for minimizing codebase size.

high_findings.title: Ruby/Shell Backtick Execution False Positive
high_findings.description: Scanner flagged markdown code spans using backticks (e.g., `worse-is-better`) as Ruby/shell backtick execution. These are markdown formatting for inline code references, not actual code execution. No bash, Ruby, or shell scripts exist in this skill.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: Markdown inline code spans (backticks) are formatting, not code execution. The skill contains no scripts or executable code of any kind.

high_findings.title: Weak Cryptographic Algorithm False Positive
high_findings.description: Scanner flagged YAML frontmatter fields as 'weak cryptographic algorithm'. The pattern match triggered on the word 'description' in YAML frontmatter. No cryptographic code exists in this skill.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: YAML frontmatter contains descriptive text fields, not cryptographic code. This is a false positive pattern match on the word 'description'.

medium_findings.title: Hardcoded URL False Positive
medium_findings.description: Scanner flagged external reference links (YouTube, InfoQ, Amazon) as 'hardcoded URL' network risk. These are legitimate documentation links in markdown files, not code making network requests. No fetch, curl, or network calls exist.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: Static documentation links are not network requests. This skill contains no code that makes network calls.

low_findings.title: System Reconnaissance False Positive
low_findings.description: Scanner flagged documentation headers like 'The Goal', 'Source Material' as system reconnaissance. This is innocent documentation terminology misinterpreted by pattern matching.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: Documentation section headers are not reconnaissance commands. No system scanning or reconnaissance code exists.

content.value_statement: Codebases naturally accumulate complexity over time, leading to more bugs and maintenance burden. This skill provides a framework for evaluating every change based on whether it reduces total code in the final codebase.
actual_capabilities: Evaluates changes by measuring total code before and after
Applies three key questions to assess every proposed modification
Loads philosophical mindsets (data-over-abstractions, simpler-is-better) to guide simplification
Detects anti-patterns that justify adding code (flexibility, separation of concerns)
Measures success by final codebase size, not effort expended
limitations: Manual-only skill that requires explicit user activation
Does not automatically refactor code - provides guidance only
Does not execute commands or modify files directly
Does not work well with frameworks that have strong conventions

use_cases.title: Refactoring Legacy Code
use_cases.description: When cleaning up technical debt in an existing codebase, use this skill to evaluate whether proposed refactoring actually reduces total code or just reorganizes complexity.

use_cases.title: Feature Request Evaluation
use_cases.description: When deciding whether to add a new feature, this skill helps assess if the benefit justifies the code cost and identifies opportunities to remove existing code.

use_cases.title: Code Review Simplification
use_cases.description: During code reviews, use this skill to challenge proposals that add abstractions, layers, or flexibility that may not be immediately necessary.

prompt_templates.title: Beginner: Simple Refactor Request
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to add validation to my user registration form. Help me implement this using the reducing-entropy skill. First, load a relevant mindset from the references directory and explain its core principle.
prompt_templates.scenario: Adding a new feature with focus on minimal code

prompt_templates.title: Intermediate: Feature Comparison
prompt_templates.prompt: Compare two implementation approaches for adding search functionality: Approach A adds a new search service with 200 lines, Approach B adds 30 lines to existing controllers. Which approach reduces entropy? Load the appropriate mindset and apply the three questions.

prompt_templates.title: Advanced: Full Codebase Review
prompt_templates.prompt: Review my authentication module (files: auth.js, token.js, session.js, refresh.js). For each file, identify what can be deleted, merged, or simplified. Apply the 'worse-is-better' mindset and explain how each change affects total code count.

prompt_templates.title: Expert: Architectural Decision
prompt_templates.prompt: Our team wants to add a caching layer between our API and database. Evaluate this decision through the reducing-entropy lens. Load the 'essential-vs-accidental' mindset and the 'locality-of-behavior' mindset. What questions should we ask? What code might become obsolete?

output_examples.input: I want to add error logging to my API endpoints
output_examples.output:
Loading 'simplicity-vs-easy' mindset...

Core principle: Simple is not the same as easy. Choosing the simple path often requires more upfront thought but results in less code.

**Three Questions Applied:**

1. What's the smallest codebase that solves this?
   - Could we use built-in logging (fewer lines) instead of a custom solution?
   - Do all 12 endpoints need logging or just the 3 that write data?

2. Does this result in less total code?
   - Current: 800 lines across API files
   - Proposal: +200 lines for custom logger + 3 lines per endpoint = +239 lines
   - Verdict: INCREASES ENTROPY - reject as-is

3. What can we delete?
   - Existing verbose try-catch blocks could be replaced with middleware (saves 30 lines)

output_examples.input: Should I create an abstraction for my three similar data loaders?
output_examples.output:
Loading 'rule-of-three' and 'data-over-abstractions' mindsets.

**Analysis:**

Your proposal fails the entropy test:
- Current: 3 loaders = 150 lines total
- Abstracted: Loader base class + 3 implementations = 220 lines
- Net change: +70 lines (more code, not less)

**Verdict: Do not abstract yet.**

The 'rule-of-three' mindset specifically warns against premature abstraction. Wait until you have 5+ similar loaders before considering an abstraction. The 'data-over-abstractions' mindset reminds us that 100 functions on one data structure beats specialized structures with limited operations.

best_practices: Always load at least one mindset from the references directory before applying this skill - the philosophical grounding helps make better trade-offs
Count actual lines before and after every change - measure the end state, not the effort
When tempted to add flexibility, ask 'for what?' - YAGNI (You Aren't Gonna Need It) often applies
anti_patterns: Using 'cleaner architecture' as justification to add code - organization does not reduce total lines
Accepting 'more maintainable code' without quantifying the maintenance cost savings
Avoiding churn by keeping existing code when deleting it would reduce entropy

faq.question: What is entropy in a codebase?
faq.answer: Entropy is the natural tendency of codebases to grow more complex over time. Each feature, abstraction, and layer adds to the total code that must be understood, tested, and maintained. This skill fights that tendency by biasing toward deletion.

faq.question: How is this different from standard refactoring?
faq.answer: Standard refactoring often focuses on code organization and readability within existing functionality. This skill specifically measures total code reduction - reorganization that adds lines is rejected even if it improves structure.

faq.question: When should I not use this skill?
faq.answer: Do not use this skill when the codebase is already minimal for what it does, when working in frameworks with strong conventions that you should not fight, or when regulatory requirements mandate specific structures.

faq.question: What are the reference mindsets?
faq.answer: Reference mindsets are philosophical frameworks that provide deeper grounding for simplification decisions. Examples include 'data-over-abstractions', 'essential-vs-accidental', 'worse-is-better', and 'locality-of-behavior'. You must load at least one before applying the skill.

faq.question: Does this skill write code?
faq.answer: No. This is a manual-only skill that provides guidance and evaluation criteria. It does not execute commands or directly modify files. It helps you make better decisions about what code to add, delete, or keep.

faq.question: How do I measure success with this skill?
faq.answer: Success is measured by the final codebase size - fewer lines, fewer files, fewer functions. Writing 50 lines that delete 200 lines is a win. Adding abstractions that increase total code is a loss, regardless of how organized they make the code.
